channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Panic
item.description: A mountain pass into Georgia has become a choke point for Russians fleeing the country, many of them men who faced being drafted and sent to fight in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Ksenia Ivanova and Catherine Porter
item.media:credit: Ksenia Ivanova for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sergei with his two children Daniil, 10, and Karina, 10, in a hotel room in Stepatsminda, Georgia.

item.title: Ukraine Troops Approach City That Lies in a Region Putin Illegally Annexed
item.description: They appeared to be edging closer to encircling Lyman, a strategic rail hub in the country’s east.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times

item.title: U.K. Borrowers React to Soaring Interest Rates in Mortgage Market
item.description: The financial turmoil in Britain has led to soaring interest rates, prompting many lenders to withdraw products and stoking worry among homeowners about rising costs.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Laetitia Anne and Maciej Szostek in their rented home in Loughton, England. The loan they were close to securing fell through this week.

item.title: In China, Living Not ‘With Covid,’ but With ‘Zero Covid’
item.description: The country’s strict coronavirus restrictions dictate the patterns of daily life, like waiting in line for frequent Covid tests and stocking up on extra groceries in case of lockdown.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:description: A Covid testing station in Beijing in September. The government ordered testing sites to be within a 15-minute walk in cities.

item.title: Liz Truss’ Woes Multiply After Media Blitz
item.description: In a round of interviews, the prime minister showed little sympathy for the pain that high interest rates could inflict on mortgage holders, critics said.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Prime Minister Liz Truss’s Conservative Party now trails the opposition Labour Party by 33 percentage points in polling.

item.title: Brazil Faces Big Vote in Presidential Election: Bolsonaro vs. Lula.
item.description: Brazilians voting for president on Sunday will choose between two political titans in a contest seen as a major test for one of the world’s largest democracies.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: From left: Lalo de Almeida for The New York Times; Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: The challenger, former President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, left, and the incumbent, President Jair Bolsonaro. Mr. da Silva leads in the polls.

item.title: A Year Under the Taliban
item.description: A single year of extremist rule has turned life upside down for Afghans, especially women. A photographer who has long called the country home captured the jarring changes.
item.dc:creator: Kiana Hayeri
item.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times

item.title: North Korea Launches Two Ballistic Missiles, Fourth Test in a Week
item.description: The test came a day after the United States, Japan and South Korea conducted their first joint anti-submarine exercise in five years.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: Commuters in a train station on Seoul on Friday pass a screen airing news about a recent North Korean ballistic missile launch.

item.title: French Feminist Rabbi Captivates Multifaith Crowds With Musings on Mortality
item.description: With Paris locked down over Passover, a rabbi started holding weekly talks over Zoom about Jewish texts. Thousands have tuned in to hear her reflections on death. “She is my rabbi,” said an atheist.
item.dc:creator: Julia Lieblich
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rabbi Delphine Horvilleur, center left, in black clothes, attends a Bar Mitzvah ceremony.

item.title: McKinsey Charged in South African Corruption Case
item.description: The South African branch of the global consulting firm has been charged in a corruption scandal related to its work with the country’s state-owned freight rail and port operator.
item.dc:creator: Michael Forsythe and Walt Bogdanich
item.media:credit: Gulshan Khan for The New York Times
item.media:description: The McKinsey & Company offices in Sandton, South Africa.

item.title: Blast at Education Center in Kabul Kills at Least 19
item.description: The violence was the latest to target the country’s Hazara ethnic minority and increased fears about the Taliban’s ability to provide security for all of their citizens.
item.dc:creator: Yaqoob Akbary and Christina Goldbaum
item.media:description: Relatives and medical staff tending to one of the victims of an attack on a learning center Friday in the Dasht-e-Barchi neighborhood in Kabul.

item.title: Even as Iranians Rise Up, Protests Worldwide Are Failing at Record Rates
item.description: Mass protests, once a grave threat to even the fiercest autocrat, have plummeted in effectiveness, a study shows. Factors appear to include polarization, social media and rising nationalist attitudes.
item.dc:creator: Max Fisher
item.media:description: Iranian demonstrators in the streets of the capital, Tehran, last week. Protests erupted around the country after the death of a young woman, Mahsa Amini, following her detainment in police custody.

item.title: Lula vs. Bolsonaro: What to Know About Brazil’s Election
item.description: Jair Bolsonaro has questioned the integrity of Sunday’s election and trails in polls to Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, a leftist and former president, who was imprisoned amid a corruption scandal.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times; Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Jair Bolsonaro, left, faces a challenge from Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, a former leftist president.

item.title: Military Officers Announce Coup in Burkina Faso
item.description: The officers said they had decided to remove the president because of his inability to stem a growing Islamist insurgency in the north and east of the country.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean and Elian Peltier
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Crowds gathered in protest of the country’s president, Lt. Col. Paul-Henri Sandaogo Damiba, in Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso, on Friday.

item.title: Making Friends
item.description: A psychologist and friendship expert has advice for how to make friends as an adult.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Alberta Revives Its Long-Running Campaign Against Federal Gun Controls
item.description: Alberta, later followed by Saskatchewan, has directed Mounties in the province not to participate in a buyback program for banned rifles.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Alberta has instructed Mounties within its border to not buy back banned rifles.

item.title: Battered by Floods and Trapped in Debt, Pakistani Farmers Struggle to Survive
item.description: The recent flooding has plunged small farmers in sharecropping arrangements further into debt with their landlords — a cycle that has worsened as extreme weather events become increasingly common.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum, Zia ur-Rehman and Kiana Hayeri
item.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times

item.title: Biden Calls on World to Punish Russia for Attempt to Annex Ukrainian Land
item.description: The U.S. imposed new sanctions on Russian officials and companies, and penalized foreign businesses aiding the Russian military. But officials are holding back on energy sanctions.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley and Edward Wong
item.media:description: Residents casting their votes in a referendum in Donetsk, a province of eastern Ukraine that Russia has claimed as part of its territory.

item.title: Putin Announces Ukraine Annexation, Calling West the Enemy
item.description: Declaring that Russia would annex four regions of Ukraine, which the West rejects as illegal, the Russian president accused the U.S. and its allies of “despotism’’ and “Satanism.’’
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Valerie Hopkins
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia addressed a rally and concert in Red Square on Friday celebrating Russia’s illegal annexation of four Ukrainian provinces.

item.title: Yusuf al-Qaradawi, Influential Muslim Scholar, Dies at 96
item.description: Considered a moderate by some and an extremist by others, he backed political Islam, attacked Al Qaeda and dispensed advice in a TV show viewed by millions.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.media:description: Yusuf al-Qaradawi in 2014. He was a popular advocate of political Islam and seen as a threat by Arab autocrats.

item.title: Russia Strikes Regions in Eastern Ukraine Then Declares Them Russian
item.description: The strikes killed a total of 30 civilians and wounded 107 in one of the bloodiest attacks in recent weeks.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times

item.title: Iran Soccer Stars Speak Out on Protests; Group Urges FIFA Ban
item.description: Some of the country’s most famous players have expressed support for street protests over the death of a young woman. On Thursday, an activist group went further: It asked FIFA to bar Iran from the World Cup.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith and Tariq Panja
item.media:description: Iran’s most recent game, against Senegal in Austria, was played behind closed doors after protesters turned up at a match last week.

item.title: Biden Warns Russia That the West Will Not Recognize Putin’s Actions
item.description: The president also said that Mr. Putin should not dare to take his fight into NATO territory, underscoring the unity among the alliance.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden said during a news conference at the White House on Friday that the world would not recognize Russia’s annexation efforts.

item.title: Iran Protests Continue Despite Heavy Crackdowns
item.description: Dozens of people have been killed in nationwide demonstrations that erupted almost two weeks ago after Mahsa Amini, a 22-year-old woman, died in police custody.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:description: A photo obtained from social media showing protesters in Sanandaj, the capital of Kurdistan Province, Iran, on Wednesday.

item.title: Protests Erupt in Cuba Over Blackouts Caused by Hurricane Ian
item.description: Demonstrators in Havana blocked street traffic, chanting “we want the light.” Many were angry that the lack of electricity this week has rotted what little food they had stored.
item.dc:creator: Camila Acosta and Maria Abi-Habib
item.media:description: People gathering in front of a Communist Party office in protest against the electricity shortage in Havana on Thursday.

item.title: Ukraine Submits Application to Join NATO
item.description: Ukraine’s desire to join the alliance has long been a source of conflict with Russia, which sees the eastward expansion of NATO as a existential threat.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Dan Bilefsky
item.media:credit: Ukrainian Presidential Press Office, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A photo provided by the Ukrainian Presidential Press Office of President Volodymyr Zelensky in Kyiv, Ukraine, leading a meeting on national security on Friday.

item.title: Britain Wonders, Is It Too Soon to Dramatize the Pandemic?
item.description: A new Sky Atlantic mini-series, “This England,” depicts the early days of Covid-19 in the country, with Kenneth Branagh playing Boris Johnson.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler

item.title: Despite international condemnation, Putin signs decrees declaring four regions of Ukraine part of Russia.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski, Andrew E. Kramer and Dan Bilefsky
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia giving a speech during a ceremony at the Kremlin in Moscow on Friday.

item.title: Gerrymandering, the Full Story
item.description: A Times analysis finds that the House of Representative has its fairest map in 40 years, despite recent gerrymandering.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Congressional gerrymandering is a smaller problem than it has been for much of the recent past.

item.title: Thai Prime Minister Can Stay in Power, Constitutional Court Rules
item.description: The former general seized power in a 2014 coup. The opposition had argued that the Constitution stipulated he leave office this year.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Ryn Jirenuwat
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha of Thailand. During his eight years in power, he has survived four no-confidence votes.

item.title: The Invisible Risks of a Town Ruined by Asbestos
item.description: Despite its deadly history, visitors continue to travel to the ghost town of Wittenoom.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.media:description: Once a symbol of economic prosperity, Wittenoom, Australia, is now a ghost town, polluted by decades of asbestos mining.

item.title: Ukraine Says 25 People Died in Attack on Civilians in Zaporizhzhia
item.description: Russia launched a flurry of strikes, creating scenes of destruction inside Ukraine as the Kremlin planned an elaborate, and widely dismissed, annexation ceremony.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz and Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times

item.title: Countering China, the U.S. Signs a Broad Deal to Aid Pacific Nations
item.description: Beijing’s inroads in a strategic region are pushing the Biden administration to shore up withered ties.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden with Pacific Island leaders in Washington on Thursday.

item.title: Putin is expected to illegally annex Russian-occupied parts of Ukraine following sham votes.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky
item.media:description: A mobile polling site set up for a referendum in Mariupol, in the Donetsk region of eastern Ukraine, on Saturday.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Russia moves to annex Ukrainian territory.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Russian soldiers gather on Red Square Thursday, as the area is closed prior to a ceremony claiming the annexation of four Ukrainian provinces. Banners on the stage read: “Donetsk, Luhansk, Zaporizka, Kherson — Russia!”

item.title: Putin to Announce Ukraine Annexation Plans on Friday
item.description: There was no sign that any other country would recognize Russia’s move, but Mr. Putin may try to use the plans to shift attention away from his losses on the battlefield.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: A concert stage being prepared in Moscow’s Red Square on Thursday, ahead of celebrations planned for Russia’s expected announcement on Friday of its illegal annexation of four regions of Ukraine.

item.title: Downpours From Ian Prompt Florida Treatment Plants to Release Waste
item.description: Concern turns to industrial sites and huge farms farther north as the storm heads toward South Carolina.
item.dc:creator: Winston Choi-Schagrin
item.media:description: Reservoirs at Piney Point, a phosphate plant in Palmetto, Fla., that is in the process of being shut down.

item.title: Putin Plans Annexation of Ukraine Territories. Here’s What to Know.
item.description: The Kremlin is using pageantry and a show of adhering to Russian legal formalities to give the move a veneer of legitimacy.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: A local resident rides past an abandoned Russian tank in Kramatorsk, eastern Ukraine, on Thursday.

item.title: With annexation plans, Putin escalates a battle of wills with the West.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: A giant poster in Luhansk, Ukraine, on Wednesday declared, “With Russia forever!” as Russia appeared poised to try to annex the region.

item.title: Russia Plans to Annex Land in Ukraine
item.description: Plus the destruction from Hurricane Ian and Zambia’s honeymoon.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:description: Banners read “Donetsk, Luhansk, Zaporizhzhia, Kherson — Russia!” in Red Square in central Moscow on Wednesday.

item.title: The U.S. denounces Russia’s move to annex parts of Ukraine as a ‘land grab.’
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson
item.media:description: A police officer in front of Red Square in Moscow on Thursday.

item.title: Shakira Is Accused of Tax Evasion in Spain. Here’s What We Know.
item.description: Prosecutors have charged the Colombian singer and pop star with six counts of tax fraud for failing to pay 14.5 million euros in income taxes. She could face a steep fine and a prison sentence.
item.dc:creator: Remy Tumin and José Bautista
item.media:description: Shakira arriving for the screening of “Elvis” during the Cannes Film Festival in May. She has been wrapped in a tax evasion case in Spain.

item.title: US Penalizes Chinese Companies for Aiding Iran’s Oil Exports
item.description: The move suggests a more aggressive approach by the Biden administration after talks to revive a 2015 nuclear deal faltered.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: An oil tanker carrying crude oil imported from Iran at the Port of Zhoushan in China’s Zhejiang Province.

item.title: Vatican Disciplined Nobel Laureate Bishop Over Child Abuse Claims
item.description: After accusations against him became public, the Vatican said that in 2020 it had punished Bishop Carlos Ximenes Belo, a hero of the independence movement in his native East Timor.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Glenn Campbell/The Sydney Morning Herald/Fairfax Media, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Bishop Carlos Ximenes Belo in Dili, East Timor, in 2006.

item.title: Gas Flares Might Release More Methane Than Thought, Study Finds
item.description: Flaring, meant to burn off the planet-warming gas at industrial sites, doesn’t always work as intended, according to researchers.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain
item.media:description: A flare in the Permian Basin in Midland, Texas. Methane is a stronger, though shorter-lived, greenhouse gas than carbon dioxide.

item.title: Putin Concedes That Some Men Were Wrongly Drafted
item.description: The Russian president’s remarks came after anger with the draft spilled over into street protests across Russia.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin giving remarks to top security officials in Moscow on Thursday.

item.title: Pentagon Plans to Set Up a New Command to Arm Ukraine, Officials Say
item.description: The mission in Germany would streamline a training and assistance system that the United States and its allies created on the fly after Russia’s invasion, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers heading toward the front line near Kramatorsk, in the country’s east, in May. The Pentagon’s proposal for a new command signals that the United States expects the threat from Russia to persist for many years, current and former senior U.S. officials said.

item.title: Russia Beat and Denied Food to Prisoners of War, Ukraine Says
item.description: Evidence of Russian abuses of captives has fueled outrage and added to a litany of reports of Russian war crimes.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Security Service Of Ukraine, via Getty Images
item.media:description: This handout released by Security Service of Ukraine last week shows medical personnel assisting a Ukrainian prisoner of war after a mass prisoner exchange in Chernigiv region, Ukraine.

item.title: Zelensky’s Answer to Escalating Russian Threats: Defiance
item.description: In a nightly address, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine told Russian soldiers: “If you want to live, run.”
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Russian men who have been drafted saying goodbye to relatives at a recruiting office in Moscow on Tuesday.

item.title: Queen Elizabeth’s Death Certificate Reveals Cause and Time of Death
item.description: Queen Elizabeth died of “old age” at 3:10 p.m. on Sept. 8, the paperwork shows.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II, photographed before receiving Liz Truss for an audience at Balmoral on Sept. 6, two days before she died.

item.title: China’s ‘Absurd’ Covid Propaganda Stirs Rebellion
item.description: The use of propaganda in the country has been on overdrive in the pandemic, with some Chinese citizens arguing the language has bordered on “nonsense.”
item.dc:creator: Zixu Wang
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Covid testing booth in Beijing last week. In some cases, Chinese citizens are required to get a coronavirus test three times a week.

item.title: North Korea Fires Two Missiles, Third Test in a Week
item.description: The test took place hours after Vice President Kamala Harris met with South Korea’s president to discuss their nations’ alliance.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:description: In a Seoul railroad station on Thursday, file footage of earlier North Korean military activity illustrated a news report about its most recent missile launch.

item.title: Mexico Named Deadliest Country for Environmental Activists
item.description: A new report from the watchdog group Global Witness found that 54 land rights activists were killed in Mexico last year, the most of any country.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Lopez
item.media:description: Mourners attending the burial service for the Indigenous rights leader Tomas Rojo in the Yaqui Indigenous community Vicam, in the Mexican state of Sonora, in July 2021.

item.title: Hospitals in Coastal Cities Risk Flooding Even in ‘Weak’ Hurricanes, Study Finds
item.description: In a third of the 78 cities examined on the Atlantic and Gulf coasts, half or more of hospitals were at risk from a Category 2 storm, the researchers said.
item.dc:creator: Elena Shao
item.media:credit: Johnny Milano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Flood barriers were erected in front of Tampa General Hospital in preparation for Hurricane Ian.

item.title: Finland Closes Border to Russian Tourists
item.description: The long-planned move closes off the last land route into the European Union for people fleeing Russia’s military mobilization effort.
item.dc:creator: Johanna Lemola
item.media:description: Vehicles coming from Russia in line at Finland’s Vaalimaa checkpoint on Wednesday.

item.title: The Kashmiri Chef Foraging on Precarious Soil
item.description: For Prateek Sadhu, gathering native ingredients in the conflict zone where he grew up is the only way of asserting Kashmir’s tenuous place in the world.
item.dc:creator: Ligaya Mishan and Anu Kumar

item.title: What to Know About Ian and Climate Change
item.description: We have the latest on Hurricane Ian, another storm to gather strength with frightening speed.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt, Claire Moses and Ian Prasad Philbrick
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tampa, Fla., as Hurricane Ian hit.

item.title: Russia Plans to Illegally Annex Lands It Invaded, Even as Its Military Falters
item.description: Even though Russia has failed to fully control the four territories it seeks to annex, the Kremlin is preparing a show designed to present a sheen of legitimacy to its illegal takeover.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Casting a ballot during a referendum while an armed Russian serviceman stood guard, in Luhansk, on Tuesday.

item.title: Felicien Kabuga, Rwanda Genocide Tribunal’s Most Wanted, Is on Trial
item.description: Félicien Kabuga lived on the run for 23 years before his arrest in France in 2020. He is accused of backing the groups that oversaw the killing of hundreds of thousands of people in 1994.
item.dc:creator: Marlise Simons
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Individuals killed during the 1994 Rwandan genocide, from a display at the Kigali Genocide Memorial. At least 800,000 died.

item.title: The Last Days of an Outback Town Where Every Breath Can Be Toxic
item.description: The town of Wittenoom, ruined by asbestos mining, will be wiped off the face of the earth. But first the government had to remove those who wanted to stay.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang and Matthew Abbott
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.media:description: Once a symbol of economic prosperity, Wittenoom, Australia, is now a ghost town, polluted by decades of asbestos mining.

item.title: Brazil’s Lula Is Out of Prison and Trying to Defeat Bolsonaro
item.description: Former President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva is trying to cap a stunning political comeback by defeating the incumbent Jair Bolsonaro in Brazil’s elections on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Flávia Milhorance
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mr. da Silva has taken to comparing himself to Nelson Mandela, Mahatma Gandhi and Martin Luther King Jr., political prisoners who expanded their movements after they were freed.

item.title: Despite Iran’s Efforts to Block Internet, Technology Has Helped Fuel Outrage
item.description: Online, Iranians engage in a world their leaders don’t want them to see.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:description: Iranians looking at their phones in Tehran last month.
